ud4.6:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud4.6:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud4.6:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā piṇḍolabhāradvājo bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya āraññiko piṇḍapātiko paṃsukūliko tecīvariko appiccho santuṭṭho pavivitto asaṃsaṭṭho āraddhavīriyo dhutavādo adhicittamanuyutto.
ud4.6:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight. He was one who lived in the wilderness, ate only almsfood, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes. He was of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic, an advocate of austerities, dedicated to the higher mind.

ud4.6:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ piṇḍolabhāradvājaṃ avidūre nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya āraññikaṃ piṇḍapātikaṃ paṃsukūlikaṃ tecīvarikaṃ appicchaṃ santuṭṭhaṃ pavivittaṃ asaṃsaṭṭhaṃ āraddhavīriyaṃ dhutavādaṃ adhicittamanuyuttaṃ.
ud4.6:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw him meditating there.

ud4.6:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud4.6:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud4.6:4.6.eng: this is the instruction of the Buddhas.”

ud4.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud4.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud4.7:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya appiccho santuṭṭho pavivitto asaṃsaṭṭho āraddhavīriyo adhicittamanuyutto.
ud4.7:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight. He was of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, energetic, dedicated to the higher mind.

ud4.7:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ avidūre nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya appicchaṃ santuṭṭhaṃ pavivittaṃ asaṃsaṭṭhaṃ āraddhavīriyaṃ adhicittamanuyuttaṃ.
ud4.7:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw him meditating there.

ud4.7:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud4.7:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud4.7:4.2.eng: training in the ways of sagacity:

ud4.7:4.3.eng: there are no sorrows for the unaffected,

ud4.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud4.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud4.8:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.
ud4.8:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And he received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

ud4.8:1.4.pli: Bhikkhusaṅghopi sakkato hoti garukato mānito pūjito apacito lābhī cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.
ud4.8:1.4.eng: And the mendicant Saṅgha was also honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they received robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

ud4.8:1.5.pli: Aññatitthiyā pana paribbājakā asakkatā honti agarukatā amānitā apūjitā anapacitā na lābhino cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ.
ud4.8:1.5.eng: But the wanderers who followed other religions were not honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed. And they didn’t receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

ud4.8:2.1.pli: Atha kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā bhagavato sakkāraṃ asahamānā bhikkhusaṅghassa ca yena sundarī paribbājikā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā sundariṃ paribbājikaṃ etadavocuṃ:
ud4.8:2.1.eng: Then those wanderers who followed other religions, unable to bear the esteem of the mendicant Sangha, approached the female wanderer Sundarī and said,

ud4.8:2.2.eng: “Sister, are you able to do something for the welfare of your kin?”
ud4.8:2.2.comm: Ānandajoti has “venture”, Ṭhānissaro has “dare”, but a similar phrase at Kd 8:12.1.5 clearly has the weaker sense of “able”, per Ireland and commentary (ussahasīti sakkosi).

ud4.8:2.4.comm: Accepting the variant kiṁ mayā sakkā, which is found in all similar passages. Reading, as Ṭhānissaro and Ānandajoti do, “what can I not do” is pleasingly dramatic, but not very idiomatic for Pali. Far more likely a simple reinforcement is meant. Commentary ignores this phrase, implying it thought there was nothing unusual.

ud4.8:2.5.eng: I’d even give my life for the welfare of my kin.”

ud4.8:3.1.eng: “Well then, sister, frequently visit Jeta’s Grove.”

ud4.8:3.2.pli: “Evaṃ, ayyā”ti kho sundarī paribbājikā tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ paṭissutvā abhikkhaṇaṃ jetavanaṃ agamāsi.
ud4.8:3.2.eng: “Yes, masters,” she replied, and did as they asked.

ud4.8:4.2.pli: “vodiṭṭhā kho sundarī paribbājikā bahujanena abhikkhaṇaṃ jetavanaṃ gacchantī”ti.
ud4.8:4.2.eng: that Sundarī had been clearly seen by many people frequently visiting Jeta’s Grove,

ud4.8:4.3.pli: Atha naṃ jīvitā voropetvā tattheva jetavanassa parikhākūpe nikkhipitvā yena rājā pasenadi kosalo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ etadavocuṃ:
ud4.8:4.3.eng: they killed her and dumped her in the ditch around Jeta’s Grove. Then they went to see King Pasenadi of Kosala and said to him,

ud4.8:4.4.pli: “yā sā, mahārāja, sundarī paribbājikā; sā no na dissatī”ti.
ud4.8:4.4.eng: “Great king, we cannot find the female wanderer Sundarī.”

ud4.8:4.5.eng: “But where do you suspect she is?”

ud4.8:5.1.pli: Atha kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā jetavanaṃ vicinitvā yathānikkhittaṃ parikhākūpā uddharitvā mañcakaṃ āropetvā sāvatthiṃ pavesetvā rathiyāya rathiyaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā manusse ujjhāpesuṃ:
ud4.8:5.1.eng: So the wanderers searched Jeta’s Grove. They pulled her body up from the ditch where they had dumped it, and lifted it on a bier. Having entered Sāvatthī, they went from street to street and from square to square, complaining to people:

ud4.8:6.1.eng: “See the deed of the ascetics who follow the Sakyan!

ud4.8:6.2.pli: Alajjino ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā dussīlā pāpadhammā musāvādino abrahmacārino.
ud4.8:6.2.eng: Shameless are these ascetics who follow the Sakyan, immoral and wicked. They are liars and unchaste.

ud4.8:6.3.pli: Ime hi nāma dhammacārino samacārino brahmacārino saccavādino sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā paṭijānissanti.
ud4.8:6.3.eng: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be chaste, truthful, ethical, and of good character.
ud4.8:6.3.comm: The idiom ime hi nāma appears mildly emphatic in a disparaging way. Compare kathaṁ hi nāma just below.

ud4.8:6.4.pli: Natthi imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, natthi imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ.
ud4.8:6.4.eng: But they have no asceticism, no spirituality.

ud4.8:6.5.pli: Naṭṭhaṃ imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, naṭṭhaṃ imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ.
ud4.8:6.5.eng: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!

ud4.8:6.6.pli: Kuto imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, kuto imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ?
ud4.8:6.6.eng: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?

ud4.8:6.7.pli: Apagatā ime sāmaññā, apagatā ime brahmaññā.
ud4.8:6.7.eng: They have abandoned asceticism and spirituality!

ud4.8:6.8.pli: Kathañhi nāma puriso purisakiccaṃ karitvā itthiṃ jīvitā voropessatī”ti.
ud4.8:6.8.eng: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”

ud4.8:7.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sāvatthiyaṃ manussā bhikkhū disvā asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosanti paribhāsanti rosanti vihesanti:
ud4.8:7.1.eng: Then at that time when the people of Sāvatthī saw the mendicants they abused and insulted them with rude, harsh words:

ud4.8:8.1.pli: “Alajjino ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā dussīlā pāpadhammā musāvādino abrahmacārino.
ud4.8:8.1.eng: “Shameless are these ascetics who follow the Sakyan, immoral, wicked, liars, and fake chastes.

ud4.8:8.2.pli: Ime hi nāma dhammacārino samacārino brahmacārino saccavādino sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā paṭijānissanti.
ud4.8:8.2.eng: Sure, they claim to be of principled and moral conduct, to be chaste, truthful, ethical, and of good character.

ud4.8:8.3.pli: Natthi imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, natthi imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ.
ud4.8:8.3.eng: But they have no asceticism, no spirituality.

ud4.8:8.4.pli: Naṭṭhaṃ imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, naṭṭhaṃ imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ.
ud4.8:8.4.eng: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!

ud4.8:8.5.pli: Kuto imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, kuto imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ?
ud4.8:8.5.eng: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?

ud4.8:8.6.pli: Apagatā ime sāmaññā, apagatā ime brahmaññā.
ud4.8:8.6.eng: They have abandoned asceticism and spirituality!

ud4.8:8.7.pli: Kathañhi nāma puriso purisakiccaṃ karitvā itthiṃ jīvitā voropessatī”ti.
ud4.8:8.7.eng: How on earth can a man, having done a man’s business, kill a woman!”

ud4.8:9.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃsu.
ud4.8:9.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

ud4.8:9.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
ud4.8:9.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

ud4.8:10.1.pli: “Etarahi, bhante, sāvatthiyaṃ manussā bhikkhū disvā asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosanti paribhāsanti rosanti vihesanti:

ud4.8:10.2.pli: ‘alajjino ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā dussīlā pāpadhammā musāvādino abrahmacārino.

ud4.8:10.3.pli: Ime hi nāma dhammacārino samacārino brahmacārino saccavādino sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā paṭijānissanti.

ud4.8:10.4.pli: Natthi imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, natthi imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ.

ud4.8:10.5.pli: Naṭṭhaṃ imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, naṭṭhaṃ imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ.

ud4.8:10.6.pli: Kuto imesaṃ sāmaññaṃ, kuto imesaṃ brahmaññaṃ?

ud4.8:10.7.pli: Apagatā ime sāmaññā, apagatā ime brahmaññā.

ud4.8:10.8.pli: Kathañhi nāma puriso purisakiccaṃ karitvā itthiṃ jīvitā voropessatī’”ti.

ud4.8:11.1.pli: “Neso, bhikkhave, saddo ciraṃ bhavissati sattāhameva bhavissati. Sattāhassa accayena antaradhāyissati.
ud4.8:11.1.eng: “That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.

ud4.8:11.2.pli: Tena hi, bhikkhave, ye manussā bhikkhū disvā asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosanti paribhāsanti rosanti vihesanti, te tumhe imāya gāthāya paṭicodetha:
ud4.8:11.2.eng: So you may respond to those critics with this verse:

ud4.8:12.2.pli: Yo vāpi katvā na karomi cāha;
ud4.8:12.2.eng: as does one who denies what they did.

ud4.8:12.3.eng: Both are equal in the hereafter,

ud4.8:13.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā ye manussā bhikkhū disvā asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosanti paribhāsanti rosanti vihesanti te imāya gāthāya paṭicodenti:
ud4.8:13.1.eng: The mendicants memorized that verse in the Buddha’s presence, then used it to respond to those critics.

ud4.8:14.2.pli: Yo vāpi katvā na karomi cāha;

ud4.8:15.2.pli: “akārakā ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā, nayimehi kataṃ, sapantime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā”ti.
ud4.8:15.2.eng: “These ascetics who follow the Sakyan didn’t do it, it was not done by them, they swear it.”

ud4.8:15.3.pli: Neva so saddo ciraṃ ahosi. Sattāhameva ahosi. Sattāhassa accayena antaradhāyi.
ud4.8:15.3.eng: That rumor didn’t last long. It was seven days, then it vanished.

ud4.8:16.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavato etadavocuṃ:
ud4.8:16.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

ud4.8:17.2.eng: How well said this was by the Buddha:

ud4.8:17.3.pli: ‘neso, bhikkhave, saddo ciraṃ bhavissati. Sattāhameva bhavissati. Sattāhassa accayena antaradhāyissatī’ti.
ud4.8:17.3.eng: ‘That rumor, mendicants, won’t last long. It will only be seven days, then it will vanish.’

ud4.8:18.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud4.8:18.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud4.8:19.1.eng: “People out of control stab with words,

ud4.8:19.2.eng: like they stab a tusker in battle with darts.

ud4.8:19.3.eng: When they hear a harsh word spoken,

ud4.8:19.4.eng: a mendicant should endure with no anger in heart.”

ud4.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
ud4.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

ud4.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmato upasenassa vaṅgantaputtassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
ud4.9:1.3.eng: Then as Venerable Upasena son of Vaṅgantā was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:

ud4.9:1.5.pli: satthā ca me bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho;
ud4.9:1.5.eng: My Teacher is the Blessed One, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.

ud4.9:1.6.pli: svākkhāte camhi dhammavinaye agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito;
ud4.9:1.6.eng: Well explained is the teaching and training in which I have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.

ud4.9:1.7.eng: My spiritual companions are ethical and of good character.

ud4.9:1.9.eng: My mind is unified and serene.

ud4.9:1.10.eng: I am a perfected one who has ended the defilements.

ud4.9:1.11.eng: I am of great might and power.

ud4.9:1.12.eng: My life has been good, and my death will be good.”

ud4.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmato upasenassa vaṅgantaputtassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud4.9:2.1.eng: Then, knowing that Venerable Upasena’s train of thought, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud4.9:3.1.eng: “One who has no guilt in life,

ud4.9:3.3.eng: that attentive one who has seen the truth,

ud4.9:4.1.eng: For the mendicant with peaceful mind,

ud4.9:4.2.eng: who has cut off craving for continued existence,

ud4.9:4.4.eng: there’ll be no more future lives for them.”

ud5.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud5.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud5.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo mallikāya deviyā saddhiṃ uparipāsādavaragato hoti.
ud5.1:1.3.eng: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala was upstairs in the royal longhouse together with Queen Mallikā.

ud5.1:1.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo mallikaṃ deviṃ etadavoca:
ud5.1:1.4.eng: Then King Pasenadi addressed Queen Mallikā,

ud5.1:1.5.pli: “atthi nu kho te, mallike, kocañño attanā piyataro”ti?
ud5.1:1.5.eng: “Mallikā, is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?”

ud5.1:2.1.pli: “Natthi kho me, mahārāja, kocañño attanā piyataro.

ud5.1:2.2.pli: Tuyhaṃ pana, mahārāja, atthañño koci attanā piyataro”ti?
ud5.1:2.2.eng: But is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?”

ud5.1:2.3.pli: “Mayhampi kho, mallike, natthañño koci attanā piyataro”ti.

ud5.1:3.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo pāsādā orohitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud5.1:3.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala came downstairs from the stilt longhouse, went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

ud5.1:4.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, mallikāya deviyā saddhiṃ uparipāsādavaragato mallikaṃ deviṃ etadavocaṃ:

ud5.1:4.2.pli: ‘atthi nu kho te, mallike, kocañño attanā piyataro’ti?

ud5.1:4.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, mallikā devī maṃ etadavoca:

ud5.1:4.4.pli: ‘natthi kho me, mahārāja, kocañño attanā piyataro.

ud5.1:4.5.pli: Tuyhaṃ pana, mahārāja, atthañño koci attanā piyataro’ti?

ud5.1:4.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, mallikaṃ deviṃ etadavocaṃ:

ud5.1:4.7.pli: ‘mayhampi kho, mallike, natthañño koci attanā piyataro’”ti.

ud5.1:5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud5.1:5.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud5.1:6.1.eng: “Having explored every quarter with the mind,

ud5.1:6.2.eng: one finds no-one dearer than oneself.

ud5.1:6.3.eng: Likewise for others, each holds themselves dear;

ud5.1:6.4.eng: so one who desires self-knowledge <j>would harm no other.”

ud5.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud5.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud5.10:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā cūḷapanthako bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
ud5.10:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Cūḷapanthaka was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence.

ud5.10:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ cūḷapanthakaṃ avidūre nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
ud5.10:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw him meditating there.

ud5.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud5.10:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud5.10:4.3.eng: a mendicant focusing on this mindfulness

ud5.10:4.5.eng: And when they have done so,

ud5.10:4.6.eng: they vanish from the King of Death.”

ud5.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud5.2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud5.2:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud5.2:1.3.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

ud5.2:1.5.pli: Yāva appāyukā hi, bhante, bhagavato mātā ahosi, sattāhajāte bhagavati bhagavato mātā kālamakāsi, tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapajjī”ti.
ud5.2:1.5.eng: How short-lived was the Blessed One’s mother! For seven days after the Blessed One was born, his mother passed away and was reborn in the host of joyful gods.”
ud5.2:1.5.comm: Here I use “Blessed One” rather than my usual “Buddha” for bhagavā. Normally the difference is immaterial, as it is simply the most common way to address the Buddha. In this case, however, the passage Ānanda is referring to uses bodhisatta, and it is quite striking that he changes it here.

ud5.2:2.1.pli: “Evametaṃ, ānanda, appāyukā hi, ānanda, bodhisattamātaro honti.
ud5.2:2.1.eng: “That’s so true, Ānanda! For the mothers of beings intent of awakening are short-lived.
ud5.2:2.1.comm: The Buddha switches back to bodhisatta, and depersonalizes it by using the plural.

ud5.2:2.2.pli: Sattāhajātesu bodhisattesu bodhisattamātaro kālaṃ karonti, tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapajjantī”ti.
ud5.2:2.2.eng: Seven days after the beings intent on awakening are born, their mothers pass away and are reborn in the host of joyful gods.”

ud5.2:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud5.2:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud5.2:4.2.eng: all depart, leaving the body behind.

ud5.2:4.3.eng: The skillful, understanding that all is lost,

ud5.2:4.4.eng: would keenly practice the spiritual life.”

ud5.3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
ud5.3:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

ud5.3:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahe suppabuddho nāma kuṭṭhī ahosi—
ud5.3:1.3.eng: At that time in Rājagaha there was a leper called Suppabuddha.

ud5.3:1.4.eng: He was a poor person, destitute, and pitiful.

ud5.3:1.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā mahatiyā parisāya parivuto dhammaṃ desento nisinno hoti.
ud5.3:1.5.eng: Now, at that time the Buddha was teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.

ud5.3:2.1.pli: Addasā kho suppabuddho kuṭṭhī taṃ mahājanakāyaṃ dūratova sannipatitaṃ.
ud5.3:2.1.eng: Suppabuddha saw the crowd seated off in the distance

ud5.3:2.3.pli: “nissaṃsayaṃ kho ettha kiñci khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā bhājīyati.
ud5.3:2.3.eng: “Surely some fresh and cooked foods will be distributed there.

ud5.3:2.4.eng: Why don’t I approach the crowd?

ud5.3:2.5.pli: Appeva nāmettha kiñci khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā labheyyan”ti.
ud5.3:2.5.eng: Hopefully I’ll get something to eat.”

ud5.3:3.1.pli: Atha kho suppabuddho kuṭṭhī yena so mahājanakāyo tenupasaṅkami.

ud5.3:3.2.pli: Addasā kho suppabuddho kuṭṭhī bhagavantaṃ mahatiyā parisāya parivutaṃ dhammaṃ desentaṃ nisinnaṃ.
ud5.3:3.2.eng: where he saw the Buddha teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.

ud5.3:3.3.eng: When he saw this he thought,

ud5.3:3.4.pli: “na kho ettha kiñci khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā bhājīyati.

ud5.3:3.5.pli: Samaṇo ayaṃ gotamo parisati dhammaṃ deseti.
ud5.3:3.5.eng: The ascetic Gotama is teaching Dhamma in an assembly.

ud5.3:3.6.eng: Why don’t I also listen to the teaching?”

ud5.3:3.7.eng: Right there he sat down to one side, thinking,

ud5.3:3.8.eng: “I also will listen to the teaching.”

ud5.3:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sabbāvantaṃ parisaṃ cetasā ceto paricca manasākāsi
ud5.3:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha focused on encompassing the minds of everyone in the assembly, thinking,

ud5.3:4.2.pli: “ko nu kho idha bhabbo dhammaṃ viññātun”ti?
ud5.3:4.2.eng: “Who here is capable of understanding the teaching?”

ud5.3:4.3.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā suppabuddhaṃ kuṭṭhiṃ tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinnaṃ.
ud5.3:4.3.eng: He saw Suppabuddha sitting in the assembly,
ud5.3:4.3.comm: It’s interesting to note that, despite the perhaps derogatory sense of kuṭṭhi (“leper”), there is no question that Suppabuddha sits in the assembly and is not physically exlcuded.

ud5.3:4.5.eng: “He is capable of understanding the teaching.”

ud5.3:4.6.pli: Suppabuddhaṃ kuṭṭhiṃ ārabbha anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
ud5.3:4.6.eng: He gave a step by step talk especially for Suppabuddha

ud5.3:4.7.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ; kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ; nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
ud5.3:4.7.eng: on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.

ud5.3:4.8.pli: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi suppabuddhaṃ kuṭṭhiṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā taṃ pakāsesi—
ud5.3:4.8.eng: When the Buddha knew that Suppabuddha’s mind was ready, supple, without hindrances, elated, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:

ud5.3:4.9.eng: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

ud5.3:4.10.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
ud5.3:4.10.eng: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,

ud5.3:4.11.pli: evamevaṃ suppabuddhassa kuṭṭhissa tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
ud5.3:4.11.eng: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in Suppabuddha:

ud5.3:4.12.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

ud5.3:5.1.pli: Atha kho suppabuddho kuṭṭhī diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthu sāsane uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho suppabuddho kuṭṭhī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud5.3:5.1.eng: Then Suppabuddha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He rose from his seat and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said:

ud5.3:6.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
ud5.3:6.2.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

ud5.3:6.3.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
ud5.3:6.3.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

ud5.3:6.4.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
ud5.3:6.4.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

ud5.3:7.1.pli: Atha kho suppabuddho kuṭṭhī bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito bhagavatā bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
ud5.3:7.1.eng: After Suppabuddha had been educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.

ud5.3:7.2.pli: Atha kho acirapakkantaṃ suppabuddhaṃ kuṭṭhiṃ gāvī taruṇavacchā adhipatitvā jīvitā voropesi.
ud5.3:7.2.eng: But soon after Suppabuddha had left, a cow with a baby calf charged at him and took his life.

ud5.3:8.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
ud5.3:8.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said,

ud5.3:8.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:

ud5.3:8.3.pli: “yo so, bhante, suppabuddho nāma kuṭṭhī bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito, so kālaṅkato.
ud5.3:8.3.eng: “The leper named Suppabuddha, after being educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired with a Dhamma talk by the Buddha, has passed away.

ud5.3:8.4.eng: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

ud5.3:9.1.pli: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, suppabuddho kuṭṭhī; paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṃ; na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vihesesi.
ud5.3:9.1.eng: “Mendicants, Suppabuddha was astute. He practiced in line with the teaching, and did not trouble me about the teachings.

ud5.3:9.2.pli: Suppabuddho, bhikkhave, kuṭṭhī tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
ud5.3:9.2.eng: With the ending of three fetters, Suppabuddha is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

ud5.3:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud5.3:10.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,

ud5.3:10.2.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo yena suppabuddho kuṭṭhī ahosi—
ud5.3:10.2.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why Suppabuddha became a leper,

ud5.3:10.3.eng: a poor person, destitute, and pitiful?”

ud5.3:11.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, suppabuddho kuṭṭhī imasmiṃyeva rājagahe seṭṭhiputto ahosi.
ud5.3:11.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Suppabuddha used to be a financier’s son right here in Rājagaha.

ud5.3:11.2.pli: So uyyānabhūmiṃ niyyanto addasa tagarasikhiṃ paccekabuddhaṃ nagaraṃ piṇḍāya pavisantaṃ.
ud5.3:11.2.eng: On his way to visit a park, he saw Tagarasikhī, an Independent Buddha, entering the city for alms.

ud5.3:11.3.eng: When he saw this he thought,

ud5.3:11.4.eng: “Who is this leper wandering about with his leper’s robe?”

ud5.3:11.5.eng: Before leaving, he spat on the ground and turned his left side to Tagarasikhī.
ud5.3:11.5.comm: At Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa 3.2.9b, a titan renders the sacrificial ground impure by spitting on it.

ud5.3:11.6.pli: So tassa kammassa vipākena bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni bahūni vassasatasahassāni niraye paccittha.
ud5.3:11.6.eng: As a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, for many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years.

ud5.3:11.7.pli: Tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena imasmiṃyeva rājagahe kuṭṭhī ahosi manussadaliddo, manussakapaṇo, manussavarāko.
ud5.3:11.7.eng: And as a residual result of that same deed, he became a leper right here in Rājagaha, a poor person, destitute and pitiful.

ud5.3:11.8.pli: So tathāgatappaveditaṃ dhammavinayaṃ āgamma saddhaṃ samādiyi sīlaṃ samādiyi sutaṃ samādiyi cāgaṃ samādiyi paññaṃ samādiyi.
ud5.3:11.8.eng: But owing to faith in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, he undertook ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

ud5.3:11.9.pli: So tathāgatappaveditaṃ dhammavinayaṃ āgamma saddhaṃ samādiyitvā sīlaṃ samādiyitvā sutaṃ samādiyitvā cāgaṃ samādiyitvā paññaṃ samādiyitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapanno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
ud5.3:11.9.eng: After undertaking these things, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.

ud5.3:11.10.pli: So tattha aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā cā”ti.
ud5.3:11.10.eng: There he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory.”

ud5.3:12.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud5.3:12.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud5.3:13.1.eng: “As a clear-eyed man would avoid rough paths,

ud5.3:13.2.eng: so long as strength is found;

ud5.3:13.3.eng: an astute person in the living world,
